segments.text: From the moment David left the pink house on his way home, he released the almost hysterical excitement that had spread through him when she described the place where she saw Dan in her dreams.
She was able to vividly depict the fronts of the houses, the cafe, the old cars, even the colorful clothing of the people and the language they spoke.
The father paints pictures and the daughter paints descriptions, a thought suddenly occurred to him.
He was agitated and restless, unable to find peace.
Halfway home, he stopped at a public phone and called home, impatiently waiting for her hello.
Only after three rings did he hear her voice.
Nomala, I think I know where he is.
No hello, no greeting, nothing.
A large, long silence remained on the other end of the line, and then she said very quietly, you can tell me the rest when you get home.
Please drive carefully.
He stayed for another moment with the receiver in his hand, and only then did he replace it.
From the moment he said it out loud, he felt a slight relief, as if the air had escaped from a bubble that was about to burst inside him.
He continued driving slowly, leaning back, opened the window, and let the breeze gently blow on his face.
One hand on the steering wheel, the other on the window ledge, a kind of calm spreading through his body.
As soon as she began to describe her dreams, he felt himself tense.
And in a moment, he knew he recognized the place she was talking about.
He said nothing to her and forced himself to continue speaking normally, swallowing the almost hysterical feeling that swept over him.
But really, why not?
If there's anyone to share everything with, it's her.
He marveled at the warm and intimate bond that developed between them so quickly.
A bond of care.
He loved so much the openness and warmth with which she talked about her and Dan's love.
A great love, a true love, a love that seemed destined to happen, he thought to himself.
He recalled the long monologue Dan gave him over the lawn mower they were trying to fix together.
While she played in the background, the song about the special guy with sad eyes who knows that the most important thing is to love and be loved.
Even then, he knew his son was infatuated with that girl from the pink house.
He saw his sparkling eyes, his dreamy look, as if he had found answers he'd been searching for years before even realizing it.
He could almost hear Dan saying again, and how did I not see she was such a beauty?
And why do I feel like I need to protect her?
From what?
Now after visiting her in her pink fortress, he knew that this house, with its pink walls, its charming paintings,
And the enchanted garden around it was her entire essence.
She had grown from it to be who she was, from the wonderland of her childhood, and not less from the difficult days that followed her mother's death, hard days she had overcome.
Yet still, they knew so little about her.
It's strange how we refer to her as the girl, he thought.

She's already over the age of 20, but something about her slenderness, the fragile silhouette of her girlish body, with her bare feet and so simple clothing, seems to leave her in that girlish appearance.
Only the expression in her eyes and the way she talks make it clear that she possesses wisdom and life experiences akin to an adult, who has been through a thing or two in her life.
She holds a certain calm that isn't afraid of life, knowing that she's already faced the surprises they occasionally present, even the unpleasant ones.
His thoughts returned to Dan, how relieved he was to know he's not in an enemy state.
But now he began to wonder, what do we have to look for there?
What could possibly be so secretive and isolated in that almost backward country in Central America?
The funny thing is he still had two or three friends from that time, about 20 years ago, during which they spent two years there on assignment.
To this day, he sends them New Year's greetings.
He put two and two together and understood why Dan was marked as a natural candidate for this mission, whatever it may be.
He spoke fluent Spanish with a local accent, as if he were born there.
He often fought to himself how amazing it was that children pick up in an instant what adults have to break their heads to achieve.

His Dan, a brown-eyed and black-curled six-year-old, quickly blended with the local children, spoke their language, played with them in the yards, learned to play dominoes like the Last of the Dominicans, and often even beat the older ones.
Dominoes replace chess there.
They can spend hours immersed in this game.
When they were sent there, he had a momentary feeling as if he was being demoted.
But they had two magical years on that island, with its stunning sunlit beaches and coconut palms, with the simple, poor and cheerful people whose merengue dance seemed to dictate their lives.
They traveled endlessly from one side of the island to the other, discovering every corner, even the mountainous part, which was no less enchanting.
There, Dan met horses for the first time and even drew his parents into riding for leisure.
But what do we have to look for there, and whom?
The thought nagged at him.
Unnoticed, he was already on the outskirts of Bateyani, climbing the cliff with the car.
He parked it and got out slowly, as if forcing himself to hold back for another moment.
He saw Naomi standing in the doorway, looking at him with a loving and tired expression, ending with a question mark.
Only when he stood right before her did he say, he's in San Pedro.
There he let it out, and they hugged tightly, clutching each other while he heard her sobbing in his arms, also releasing the relief that swept over her knowing he wasn't in an Arab enemy state.
A little later, as they sat close together, nestled on the sofa with coffee cups in hand, he recounted how he discovered it from the girl's dream.
Naomi suddenly straightened up and almost defiantly said, that's how you know, from her dream?
Since when do you believe in dreams?
Look, Nomala, now I believe.
She's connecting with him.
He speaks to her in dreams.
She described the place in great detail, described him with a beard and beret, looking up at her and asking her to trust him, asking her to wait.
I felt the hair on the back of my neck stand up as she told it all.
We know there are such things that people tightly bound by love feel each other.
It even happened to us more than once.
How many times did you put your hand on the phone receiver, just as I was calling you, or vice versa?
And how many times did you wake up in the night when it turned out the next day that Dan participated in some raid where there were wounded?
I can't dismiss it.
She can't possibly give so many details about a place she's never even read about at the other end of the world.
Naomi rested her head on his shoulder in submission.
I hope you're right, she said.
Now tell me a little about her pink house.
